questions.question_text: What is the key benefit of Palo Alto Networks Single Pass Parallel Processing design?

choices.A: There are no benefits other than slight performance upgrades
choices.C: Only one processor is needed to complete all the functions within the box
choices.D: It allows Palo Alto Networks to add new devices to existing hardware
choices.B: It allows Palo Alto Networks to add new functions to existing hardware

discussion.content: Nonsense answers. C can't be right since PAN boxes contain multiple processors for multiple functions. Single pass means processing is done in parallel, it does not mean ALL functions are done with single processor...

Selected Answer: B
is this still valid? one comment says, its not valid?

Selected Answer: B
WARNING:

ALL QUESTIONS ARE NOT VALID NOW

I FAILED TODAY. NONE OF THESE QUESTIONS VALID
"Single Pass" >>> one processor

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

The answer is C. Single pass parallel processing ensures the evualuation of app-ID , content-ID, user-ID per patcket in one single process. The hardware parallel processing which is divided in 3 platforms: data, control, and management is the one in charge to make the software process faster since each task is divided per platform. So, answer is still C.

https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/whitepapers/single-pass-parallel-processing-architecture says: it enables high-throughput, low-latency network security, even while incorporating unprecedented features and technology

"unprecedented features and technology" - so answer should be B.

comments.content:
"With our Single-Pass Architecture, Palo Alto Networks makes
it possible to add a function to an NGFW instead of adding another security device"

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
C is wrong because their is a cpu for each layer in SP3

Selected Answer: B
B as C seams incorrect as there are multiple CPUs in every Firewall. If you read all functions as not just SP3 then you have the separate CPUs in Data & Control planes.

Selected Answer: B
Commercialy is the most used argument

Selected Answer: C
correct

choices.C: Submit a request to Palo Alto Networks to change the behavior at the next update
choices.A: Create a custom spyware signature matching the known signature with the time attribute
choices.D: Configure the Anti-Spyware profile with the number of rule counts to match the occurrence frequency
choices.B: Add a correlation object that tracks the occurrences and triggers above the desired threshold

questions.question_text:
A customer requests that a known spyware threat signature be triggered based on a rate of occurrence, for example, 10 hits in 5 seconds.
How is this goal accomplished?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct, checked in lab, what VenomX51 is saying is true.

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A
This is exactly how brute force threat ID is triggered. It watches a separate threat ID (failed auth attempt, which is an alert by default), and has a time event that if that monitored threat ID is triggered x times in y seconds by the same source IP, then the brute force threat is triggered, and can then take a different action such as block IP.

You would create a custom spyware profile to do the same; trigger when x has occurred y times in z seconds.

A correlation object does not trigger anything. It pulls data from multiple sources and can create a log entry when it's defined conditions are met.

Selected Answer: B
To trigger a known spyware threat signature based on a rate of occurrence (e.g., 10 hits in 5 seconds), you need to add a correlation object that tracks the occurrences and triggers an alert or action when the specified threshold is met. This correlation object monitors the frequency of the spyware signatures and ensures that action is taken only when the threshold is exceeded, providing more granular control over threat detection and response.

References: Palo Alto Networks Threat Prevention and Correlation Objects documentation.

BCE, as article in cojtti post suggets... but by default 'User Credential Detection' is set to disabled and needs to be configured, so D is also a possible correct answer.

comments.content: Agreed. The page below says the official steps are 1.) Enable user-id. 2.) Configure a best practice URL Filtering profile. 3.) Create a decryption policy rule. Looks like the question considers D "Enable User Credential Detection" to be a minor part of step 2. Ambiguous question IMHO.

discussion.content:
Correct

questions.question_text: Which three of the following actions must be taken to enable Credential Phishing Prevention? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Define a uniform resource locator (URL) Filtering profile.
choices.E: Define a Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) decryption rule base.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
From a sales perspective, BC are more appropriate than AB. We are selling the Palo consolidation story - fewer 3rd party devices, just use Palo for everything. So this being a pre-sales exam, I vote BC.

Selected Answer: BC
This one is tricky, I think that A is referring to the use of third-party decryption broker, but with using NGFW as packet broker, you don't need third-party device to preform decryption and hence the C option is more appropriate.

Selected Answer: BC
B and C are correct, Network Packet Broker feature replaces Decryption Broker, it means has the same characteristics part of the NGFW.

Selected Answer: AB
Please refer to:
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-networking-admin/network-packet-broker/network-packet-broker-overview

questions.question_text: Which two statements correctly describe what a Network Packet Broker does for a Palo Alto Networks NGFW? (Choose two.)

choices.C: It eliminates the need for a third-party SSL decryption option, which reduces the total number of third-party devices performing decryption.
choices.A: It provides a third-party SSL decryption option, which can increase the total number of third-party devices performing analysis and enforcement.
choices.D: It allows SSL decryption to be offloaded to the NGFW and traffic to be decrypted multiple times.
choices.B: It allows SSL decryption to be offloaded to the NGFW and traffic to be decrypted only once.
